legacy.description:
Stop Big Tech that
- launder our data
- dehumanise workers
- lobby for unsafe uses
- pollute with compute

See link for a guide to AI‚Äôs increasing harms:
legacy.name: Remmelt Ellen üõë

media.ext_alt_text:
Responsible scaling policies have 'safety-washing' spelled all over them.
Consider the original formulation by Anthropic: "Our
RSP focuses on catastrophic risks - those where an Al model directly causes large scale devastation."
In other words: our company can scale on as long as our staff/trustees do not deem the risk of a new Al model directly causing a catastrophe as sufficiently high.
Is that responsible?
It's assuming that further scaling can be risk managed.
It's assuming that just risk management protocols are enough.
Then, the company invents a new wonky risk management framework, ignoring established and more comprehensive practices¬∞.
Paul argues that this could be the basis for effective regulation. But Anthropic et al. lobbying national governments to enforce the use of that wonky risk management framework makes things worse.
It distracts from policy efforts to prevent the increasing harms. It creates a perception of safety (instead of actually ensuring safety).
Ideal for Al

legacy.full_text:
SCOOP: Anthropic just released its most advanced AI model ever.

But in doing so, it may have quietly walked back one of its safety commitments ‚Äî the kind of rule it once said would stop a release like this entirely. https://t.co/4mnoeKstXj

Anthropic committed to define ASL-4 by the time they reach ASL-3.

They have reached ASL-3. They haven‚Äôt yet defined ASL-4.

legacy.full_text: ‚ÄúAnthropic‚Äôs newly launched Claude Opus 4 model frequently tries to blackmail developers when they threaten to replace it with a new AI system and give it sensitive information about the engineers responsible for the decision‚Äù https://t.co/XteTlrn2a2

so many AI headlines over the past weeks bear out a simple point: AI companies can't reliably steer their models.

1. Anthropic can't guarantee that Claude 4 won't blackmail users if they make borderline requests

legacy.full_text: what are we doing here folks https://t.co/4r1Palp7eR

it's disturbing how many responses to evidence of misaligned behavior are now "well of COURSE it does blackmail," "well of COURSE it'd do anything not to be shut down"

those used to be the challenged premises of the AI safetyist case. so what are we now arguing about?
